questions.text: An intrauterine scan at 13th week showed a fetus with multiple long bone fractures. What disease is commonly associated with this finding?
questions.solution:
osteogenesis imperfecta

  • Also called brittle bone disease/ lobstein vrolik disease
  • Spectrum of disorders characterised by congenital defect in quantity/quality of collagen type-1, resulting in extremely weak bones that present as recurrent , multiple fractures.
  • COL 1A gene mutation
  • Autosomal dominant > autosomal recessive
  • SILLENCE classification is used in osteogenesis imperfecta
  • Clinical features:
    • Fractures with slight trauma
    • Multiple b\l symmetrical fractures (lower limb> upper limb)
    • Most common bone involved: femur>tibia
    • They have Normal fracture healing
    • Malunions are more common
    • Hyperlaxity of joints
    • Wormian bones (intrasutural bones)
    • Ring shaped epiphysis
    • Ocular signs: blue sclera, Saturn ring
    • Auditory : conductive hearing loss (otosclerosis)
    • Teeth: dentigenous imperfecta (discoloured brittle teeth most common in lower incisors)

Option a) achondroplasia is a skeletal dysplasia with dwarfism as presentation

Option c) cretinism- it’s a hypothyroidism with mental retardation and dwarfism as presentation

Option d) Marfan syndrome: it’s a autosomal dominant disorder , with tall stature and marfanoid habitus

Reference: Maheshwari textbook of orthopedics 7th edition, pg no 326

choices.text: Tibia fracture fixed with a spanning fixator
Femur fracture fixed with a spanning fixator
Periarticular knee fracture, fixed with spanning fixator

questions.text: A patient sustained a crush injury in the lower limb and was managed as shown in the image below. What procedure has been done and what could be the probable indication?
questions.solution:
EXTERNAL FIXATION:

It’s a device which stabilises the bone from outside the body

Consists of:

  • Schanz pins- goes into the bone, placed away from wound
  • Connecting rods

Ilizarov fixator: it’s a ring external fixator used for gap non unions and infected non unions, based on principle of distraction osteogenesis, so also used for bone lengthening

Periarticular fracture: fractures close to knee joint ( around proximal tibia or distal femur), its fixed using a spanning external fixator

Option a) the given image is not of iliazrov fixator

Option b) tibial fracture is fixed with simple external fixator , no need of spanning fixator

Option c) femur fracture is fixed with simple external fixator , no need of spanning fixator

Reference: Maheshwari textbook of orthopedics 7th edition pg no 19

questions.text: A child was brought to the OPD following a fall on the right shoulder while riding a bicycle. He was holding his right arm with his left hand. What is the most likely injury sustained by him?
questions.solution:
The given X-RAY shows fracture of shaft of clavicle

CLAVICULAR FRACTURE:

  • Most common fracture in humans
  • Most common fracture during birth
  • Most common site of injury - junction of medial 2/3rd and lateral 1/3rd
  • Most common complication: malunion
  • Treatment: figure of 8 brace, intramedullary nailing can also be done

Refrence: Maheshwari textbook of orthopedics 7th edition, pg no 88

questions.text: A 6yr old child has sustained an injury and his X-RAY is shown. Identify the best choice which marks the delayed set of complications seen in this injury
questions.solution:
The given X-RAY is of lateral condyle fracture of humerus

Complications of lateral condyle fracture of humerus:

  • Non-union: If unreduced, the fracture goes into non-union. This is either because of wide displacement of the fragment or a constant "pulling" force of the extensor muscles attached to it. The result is a persistent pain or growth disturbance at the distal humeral epiphysis
  • Cubitus valgus deformity: Diminished growth at the lateral side of distal humerus epiphysis results in a cubitus valgus deformity. This may result in late ulnar nerve palsy (tardy ulnar nerve palsy) because of friction neuritis of the ulnar nerve as it moves over the medial epicondyle, everytime the elbow is flexed and extended.

Reference: Maheshwari textbook of orthopedics 7th edition, pg no 103

questions.text: A male child was brought in with previous history of URTI. He currently has fever, fatigue and pain at the knee for which USG guided joint fluid aspiration was done. X-RAY shows a lytic lesion In the lower end of femur, the peripheral smear shows the following finding. What is the most probable organism that can be isolated from the joint aspirate?
questions.solution:
The given image shows gram positive organism in grape like clusters: suggestive of staphylococcus aureus

The given history is of septic arthritis- m\c organism causing it is staphylococcal aureus

Most common cause for any infection in orthopaedics is staphylococcus aureus

Special situations where staphylococcus aureus is both causative organism are:

Reference: Maheshwari textbook of orthopaedics 7th edition, pg no 175

questions.text: A 40yr old presented with multiple swelling in hand. Following finding was seen on X-ray. What is likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Multiple enchondromas/ollier’s disease

This is a non-hereditary disorder seen in childhood. In this, masses of unossified cartilage persist within the metaphysis of some long bones, usually multiple. Growth at the adjacent epiphyseal plates may be affected, leading to shortening and deformities. 30% risk of malignancy

Maffucci syndrome: This is a hereditary disorder where multiple enchondromas and cavernous haemangiomas occur together. 100% risk of malignancy.

Reference: Maheshwari textbook of orthopedics 7th edition, pg no 248

questions.text: An RTA patient presents with multiple injuries. After 2 days he develops dyspnea, petechiae involving the whole body, low PaO2 and low blood pressure. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
FAT EMBOLISM SYNDROME

This is one of the most serious complications, the essential feature being occlusion of small vessels by fat globules.

Causes: The fat globules may originate from bone marrow or adipose tissue. Fat embolism is more common following severe injuries with multiple fractures and fractures of major bones. The pathogenesis of the syndrome is not clear, but it seems likely that two events occur: (i) release of free fatty acids (by action of lipases on the neutral fat), which induces a toxic vasculitis, followed by platelet-fibrin thrombosis; and (ii) actual obstruction of small pulmonary vessels by fat globules.

Consequences: Symptoms are evident a day or so after the injury. Presenting features are in the form of two, more or less distinct types: (i) cerebral; and (ii) pulmonary. In the cerebral type, the patient becomes drowsy, restless and disoriented and gradually goes into a state of coma. In the pulmonary type, tachypnoea and tachycardia are the more prominent features. The other common feature of fat embolism is a patechial rash, usually on the front of the neck, anterior axillary folds, chest or conjunctiva. If untreated, and sometimes despite treatment, the patient develops respiratory failure and dies.

Diagnosis: In a case with multiple fractures, early diagnosis may be possible by strong suspicion. In addition to the classic clinical features, signs of retinal artery emboli (striate haemorrhages and exudates) may be present. Sputum and urine may reveal the presence of fat globules. X-ray of the chest may show a patchy pulmonary infiltration (snow storm appearance). Blood PO 2 of less than 50 mmHg may indicate impending respiratory failure.

GURD's criteria used for fat embolism syndrome

Treatment: This consists of respiratory support, heparinisation, intravenous low molecular weight dextran (Lomodex-20) and corticosteroids. An intravenous 5 percent dextrose solution with 5 percent alcohol helps in emulsification of fat globules, and is used by some.

Reference: Maheshwari textbook of orthopedics 7th edition, pg no 43

choices.text: Neuro vascular assessment and closed reduction and slab application
Neuro vascular assessment and closed reduction and cast application
Neuro vascular assessment and immediate surgery
Neuro vascular assessment and immediate open reduction

questions.text: An RTA patient presented to the emergency department with this injury. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
The given X-RAY shows posterior dislocation of knee

Posterior dislocation of knee is notorious to produce popliteal artery injury, so needs to be intervened immediately

So the management is neurovascular assessment to be done, followed by slab to be put and not cast application, because due to anticipated edema in this injury, cast (complete circumferential) application can lead to compartment syndrome, to avoid this slab is used which covers half of the circumference of the limb so compartment syndrome can be avoided.

KENNEDY CLASSIFICATION OF KNEE DISLOCATION

Reference: Maheshwari textbook of orthopedics 7th edition, pg no 146
